content.description: I came up with this name just to identify a route I was shown between Alien and The Shield. Like the other two, it’s a crimpy one - maybe more so. Because of that I was tempted to grade it higher but will start it at a .9 for now. Please weigh in on that. Like it's neighbors, the "real" climb is short - just up the lower wall. From there it's a class 4 to the anchors.
content.protection: Use the anchors for Camel’s Head.

content.description: Named for the feature near the bottom that resembles a shield, this climb, like the other ones here, is short but sweet. The “real” part of the route is basically a 25’ straight shot up to the top of the lower wall. After that you have an easy class 4 send to your top rope anchors. Note: To make this route official you need to engage the shield.
content.protection: Small gear works well on the lower wall. Top rope anchors above are big glue-ins set far apart.

content.description: Ok, I admit I haven't climbed this route in a long time. Not that it's not a good route - it is. But it's mostly for a beginner and someone learning trad. The first half of the route is the 5.6 part, the second half is pretty much a cakewalk - literally. It's like walking up a tiered wedding cake! I would say it's even a Class 4. Once up and over the dihedral on the first half is where the cakewalk begins.Oh, one thing fun about this climb is a rock feature at the lower half of the first half. It's a feature that resembles the upright stature of the male reproductive organ! :D  Don't let it distract you! Many a climber have handled it, hugged it, and even sat on it in order to ascend the route! Lol!
content.protection: Primarily a top rope route, trad placement though is abundant at the first half but long run-out for the second half. Top out to TR anchors - big glue-ins,

content.description: Climb what remains of the left end and begins the corner of the right end.  “Crux” is visible from the ground. Gain ledge, easy sandy book stairs up to top. Small gear down low, could sling the chock up high but just walk it off instead
content.location: Most obviously starts immediately left of Damnation and climbs up in the open book (to the left around the arete). Standing under damnation take a step or 2 left and climb towards that back wall.

content.description: Like The Shield, this route’s namesake is due to a little feature in the rock. This one looks like an image found by author Erich von Däniken for his infamous book/movie Chariots of the Gods. If von Däniken were a climber and stumbled on this little “guy” back in the ‘60s, it would now be world famous and probably have “worshipers” coming to Donation to “bathe” in its “energy”. Ha! Well thank goodness von Däniken didn't find it but you can! “Worshiping” can be made by a solid send of this short but challenging route. Be sure to engage the alien. “His” little sloping forehead only offers a tiny side-pull crimp but it’s necessary to make the send official.
content.protection: For this route is best to use a set of anchors and chains on top and on the side of a large block. Located between Camel anchors and Shark's Fin anchors.
content.location: Right side of the left wall. Look for alien head in the rock.

content.description:
This is technically one wall but with two distinct sections - lower and upper. The lower half is vertical and where the action is. The upper half is like a set of steps and is easily scaled. Many advanced climbers consider the climb finished at the top of the lower half, but beginners will want to take it to the top to build confidence and endurance.

 There’s a set of TR anchors to the right (as you’re looking from on top), and a set of anchors with chains on a wall section to the left of that and down.
